ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Emphasis on objectivity in analyzing historical events

I developed historical knowledge about the Middle East that I did not have prior, and learned about how to deduce historical bias and construct potential narratives of the past from scant sources. The analysis of primary sources was particularly interesting and insightful.
I gained the ability to interpret primary sources and incorporate them into my essays. My ability to analyze and write greatly improved over the course of the semester.
I learned about the empires of antiquity and the main themes of this time period.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great professor but difficult to listen to 3 hour long lectures.

The course's strengths are its focus on historical bias and the analysis of ancient materials, its weaknesses are mainly the length of each lecture and the volume of readings. It would be better if there are three lectures a week that are shorter and with fewer readings between each.
The strengths are that the course covers a very interesting period of human history that more people should be aware of
This course did a great job of producing engaging material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially as a survey course for NELC and Modern Middle East majors.

I would. Although it is intensive, I gained a rich historical knowledge and feel prepared to take more history courses at Yale (which intimidated me prior to this one). It is a good gateway into a vast and interesting area of study.
Yes it was a great intro into ancient near east studies.
